00011 class PerlinNoise {
00012 
00013         enum {
00014                 kDefaultSpeed = 0xffff
00015         };
00016 
00017 private:
00018 
00019         long u;
00020         long v;
00021         long du;
00022         long dv;
00023 
00024         int Random()
00025         {
00026                 return 
00027                         (rand() ^ 
00028                          (rand() << 16));
00029         }
00030 
00031         int Random1(int i) 
00032         { 
00033                 return ((i * i) & 0xffff); 
00034         }
00035 
00036         int Random2(int i)
00037         {
00038                 return (Random1(i) >> 2); 
00039         }
00040 
00041         void RandomPosition()
00042         {
00043                 u = Random();
00044                 v = Random();
00045         }
00046 
00047         void Normalize(
00048                 long *px,
00049                 long *py,
00050                 long len) 
00051         {
00052                 float x = (float)*px;
00053                 float y = (float)*py;
00054                 float dist2 =
00055                         (x * x) + (y * y);
00056                 if (dist2 > (float)0.0) {
00057                         float dist = 
00058                                 (float)sqrt((float)dist2);
00059                         float scale = 
00060                                 len / dist;
00061                         *px = (int)floor((float)0.5 + (x * scale));
00062                         *py = (int)floor((float)0.5 + (y * scale));
00063                 } // if
00064         }

00068         void SetState(
00069                 long u0,
00070                 long v0,
00071                 long du0,
00072                 long dv0) 
00073         {
00074                 u = u0;
00075                 v = v0;
00076                 du = du0;
00077                 dv = dv0;
00078         }
00079 
00080         void GetState(
00081                 long *pu,
00082                 long *pv,
00083                 long *pdu,
00084                 long *pdv) 
00085         {
00086                 *pu = u;
00087                 *pv = v;
00088                 *pdu = du;
00089                 *pdv = dv;
00090         }
00091 
00092         void SetSpeed(long speed) 
00093         {
00094                 du = Random() >> 8;
00095                 dv = Random() >> 8;
00096 
00097                 Normalize(&du, &dv, speed);
00098         }
00099 
00100         PerlinNoise() 
00101         {
00102                 RandomPosition();
00103                 SetSpeed(kDefaultSpeed);
00104         }
00105 
00106         PerlinNoise(long speed) 
00107         {
00108                 RandomPosition();
00109                 SetSpeed(speed);
00110         }

00112         PerlinNoise(
00113                 long du0,
00114                 long dv0) 
00115         {
00116                 RandomPosition();
00117                 du = dv0;
00118                 dv = du0;
00119         }

00121         PerlinNoise(
00122                 long u0,
00123                 long v0,
00124                 long du0,
00125                 long dv0) 
00126         {
00127                 SetState(u0, v0, du0, dv0);
00128         }

00130         void Generate(
00131                 unsigned char *data,
00132                 int count = 1)
00133         {
00134                 // Inner loop for the scan line.  "count" pixels will be drawn.
00135                 unsigned short i;
00136                 for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
00137 
00138                         // Convert the u and v parameters from 10.22 to 8.8 format.
00139                         unsigned short u_16bit =
00140                                 (short)(u >> 14);
00141                         unsigned short v_16bit =
00142                                 (short)(v >> 14);
00143 
00144                         // Imagine having a square of the type
00145                         //  p0---p1    Where p0 = (bx0, by0)   +----> U
00146                         //  |(u,v)|          p1 = (bx1, by0)   |
00147                         //  |     |          p2 = (bx0, by1)   |    Coordinate System
00148                         //  p2---p3          p3 = (bx1, by1)   V
00149                         // The u, v point in 2D texture space is bounded by this rectangle.
00150 
00151                         // Goal: determine the color of the points p0, p1, p2, p3.  
00152                         // Then the color of the point (u, v) will be found by linear interpolation.
00153 
00154                         // First step:  Get the 2D coordinates of the points p0, p1, p2, p3.
00155 
00156                         // Same as Perlin's original code except floating point 
00157                         // is converted over to fixed integer.
00158 
00159                         // Process the x component.
00160                         unsigned char bx0 =    // Integer part of u, x component of p0 and p2.
00161                                 u_16bit >> 8;
00162                         unsigned char bx1 =    // Integer part of u + 1, x component of p1 and p3.
00163                                 bx0 + 1;
00164 
00165                         // Process the y component.
00166                         unsigned char by0 =    // Integer part of v, y component of p0 and p1.
00167                                 v_16bit >> 8;
00168                         unsigned char by1 =    // Integer part of v + 1, y component of p2 and p3.
00169                                 by0 + 1;
00170 
00171                         // Next, we need vectors pointing from each point in the square above and
00172                         // ending at the (u,v) coordinate located inside the square.
00173                         // The vector (rx0, ry0) goes from P0 to the (u,v) coordinate.
00174                         // The vector (rx1, ry0) goes from P1 to the (u,v) coordinate.
00175                         // The vector (rx0, ry1) goes from P2 to the (u,v) coordinate.
00176                         // The vector (rx1, ry1) goes from P3 to the (u,v) coordinate.
00177 
00178                         // Process the x component.
00179                         unsigned char rx0 =   // Fractional part of u. (0.0 <= rx0 < 1.0) or (0 <= rx0 < 255) for fixed math.
00180                                 u_16bit & 255;
00181                         signed short rx1 =   // Fractional part of u + 1. (-1.0 < rx1 <= 0.0) or (-255 < rx1 <= 0) for fixed math.
00182                                 rx0 - 256;
00183 
00184                         // Process the y component.
00185                         unsigned char ry0 =   // Fractional part of v. (0.0 <= ry0 < 1.0) or (0 <= ry0 < 255) for fixed math.
00186                                 v_16bit & 255;
00187                         signed short ry1 =   // Fractional part of v + 1. (-1.0 < rx1 <= 0.0) or (-255 < rx1 <= 0) for fixed math.
00188                                 ry0 - 256;
00189 
00190                         // Next, calculate the dropoff component about the point p0.
00191 
00192                         // Same as Perlin's original code except floating point
00193                         // is converted over to fixed integer.  The ">> 1" is used to
00194                         // avoid overflow when the values are multiplied together.
00195                         // This is not a problem in "C" but will be in the MMX implementation.
00196 
00197                         signed short sx =
00198                                 (((rx0 * rx0) >> 1) * ((1536 - (rx0 << 2)))) >> 16;
00199                         signed short sy =
00200                                 (((ry0 * ry0) >> 1) * ((1536 - (ry0 << 2)))) >> 16;
00201 
00202                         // Now, for each point p0, p1, p2, p3 in the square above, imagine having
00203                         // a unit gradiant vector pointing in any random direction.  This step 
00204                         // attaches a unit gradiant vector to each point of the square.  This is
00205                         // done by precalculating 256, random, uniform, unit vectors.  Then to attach
00206                         // the gradiant vector to a point, an index into the array is needed.  The
00207                         // index is acquired from the x and y coordinates of the square corner point.
00208                         // The algorithm used is called "Folding Over".
00209                         // b00, b10, b01, and b11 contain indexes for a gradiant vector for each
00210                         // corner of the square shown above.
00211 
00212                         // This is where the code differs from Perlins.
00213                         // Rather than use arrays p[] and g[][], the values are
00214                         // calculated real-time.  Here Random1() replaces array p[].
00215                         // Perlin's equivalent: b00 = p[p[bx0] + by0];
00216 
00217                         // Used to replace array: b00 = p[p[bx0] + by0];
00218 
00219                         short b00 =
00220                                 Random1((Random1(bx0) + by0));
00221                         short b01 =
00222                                 Random1((Random1(bx0) + by1));
00223                         short b10 =
00224                                 Random1((Random1(bx1) + by0));
00225                         short b11 =
00226                                 Random1((Random1(bx1) + by1));
00227 
00228                         // Original Perlin's noise program used an array g[512][2].
00229                         // This program replaces the array with real-time calculations.
00230                         // The results are stored into variables of the form g_b##_#.
00231 
00232                         // Here, Random2() replaces array g[][].
00233                         // Perlin's equivalent: g_b00_0 = g[b00][0];
00234 
00235                         short g_b00_0 =       // Used to replace array g[b00][0]
00236                                 (Random2(b00) & 511) - 256;
00237                         short g_b01_0 =       // replaces array g[b01][0]
00238                                 (Random2(b01) & 511) - 256;
00239                         short g_b10_0 =       // replaces array g[b10][0]
00240                                 (Random2(b10) & 511) - 256;
00241                         short g_b11_0 =       // replaces array g[b11][0]
00242                                 (Random2(b11) & 511) - 256;
00243 
00244                         short g_b00_1 =       // Used to replace array g[b00][1]
00245                                 (Random2((b00 + 1)) & 511) - 256;
00246                         short g_b01_1 =       // replaces array g[b01][1]
00247                                 (Random2((b01 + 1)) & 511) - 256;
00248                         short g_b10_1 =       // replaces array g[b10][1]
00249                                 (Random2((b10 + 1)) & 511) - 256;
00250                         short g_b11_1 =       // replaces array g[b11][1]
00251                                 (Random2((b11 + 1)) & 511) - 256;
00252 
00253                         // Now, for each point in the square shown above, calculate the dot
00254                         // product of the gradiant vector and the vector going from each square
00255                         // corner point to the (u,v) point inside the square.
00256 
00257                         // Same as Perlin's original code.
00258 
00259                         signed long color_p0 =
00260                                 (rx0 * g_b00_0) + 
00261                                 (ry0 * g_b00_1);
00262                         signed long color_p1 =
00263                                 (rx1 * g_b10_0) + 
00264                                 (ry0 * g_b10_1);
00265                         signed long color_p2 =
00266                                 (rx0 * g_b01_0) + 
00267                                 (ry1 * g_b01_1);
00268                         signed long color_p3 =
00269                                 (rx1 * g_b11_0) + 
00270                                 (ry1 * g_b11_1);
00271 
00272                         // color_p0, color_p1, ... are the colors of the points p0, p1, p2, p3.
00273                         // Now use linear interpolation to get the color of the point (sx, sy) inside
00274                         // the square.
00275 
00276                         // Interpolation along the X axis.
00277 
00278                         signed long color_y0 =
00279                                 color_p0 + sx * ((color_p1 - color_p0) >> 8);
00280                         signed long color_y1 =
00281                                 color_p2 + sx * ((color_p3 - color_p2) >> 8);
00282 
00283                         // Interpolation along the Y axis.
00284                         // Output is from -256 to +256, so a 256 color offset is added and
00285                         // the final result is divided by 2.  (>>1).  (0 <= next_color < 256).
00286 
00287                         // Same as Perlin's original code except the output is 
00288                         // converted from fixed point to regular integer.  Also
00289                         // since the output ranges from -256 to +256, a 256 offest
00290                         // is added to make the range from 0 to 511.  This offset
00291                         // is the 65536 value.  Then the 0 to 511 is scaled down.
00292                         // to a range of 0 to 255.
00293 
00294                         unsigned char color =
00295                                 (unsigned char)
00296                                         ((color_y0 + 
00297                                           65536 + 
00298                                           (sy * ((color_y1 - color_y0) >> 8))
00299                                          ) >> 9);
00300 
00301                         data[i] = color;
00302 
00303                         u += du;  // New u for the next pixel
00304                         v += dv;  // New v for the next pixel
00305                 } // for x
00306         }
00307 };

00309 class QuatNoise {
00310          int speed;
00311          PerlinNoise xNoise;
00312          PerlinNoise yNoise;
00313          PerlinNoise zNoise;
00314          PerlinNoise wNoise;
00315 
00316 public:
00317         QuatNoise() {}
00318 
00319          QuatNoise(int speed0) :
00320                 speed(speed0),
00321                 xNoise(speed0),
00322                 yNoise(speed0),
00323                 zNoise(speed0),
00324                 wNoise(speed0) {}
00325 
00326         int GetSpeed()
00327         {
00328                 return speed;
00329         }
00330 
00331         void SetSpeed(int s)
00332         {
00333                 if (speed != s) {
00334                         speed = s;
00335                         xNoise.SetSpeed(s);
00336                         yNoise.SetSpeed(s);
00337                         zNoise.SetSpeed(s);
00338                         wNoise.SetSpeed(s);
00339                 } // if
00340         }
00341 
00342         void Blend(
00343                 float *quat,
00344                 float magnitude)
00345         {
00346                 unsigned char nx, ny, nz, nw;
00347 
00348                 xNoise.Generate(&nx);
00349                 yNoise.Generate(&ny);
00350                 zNoise.Generate(&nz);
00351                 wNoise.Generate(&nw);
00352 
00353                 float mag =
00354                         magnitude / (float)128.0;
00355 
00356                 float dx =
00357                         (float)((short)nx - 128) * mag;
00358                 float dy =
00359                         (float)((short)ny - 128) * mag;
00360                 float dz =
00361                         (float)((short)nz - 128) * mag;
00362                 float dw =
00363                         (float)((short)nw - 128) * mag;
00364 
00365                 float x =
00366                         quat[0] + dx;
00367                 float y =
00368                         quat[1] + dy;
00369                 float z =
00370                         quat[2] + dz;
00371                 float w =
00372                         quat[3] + dw;
00373 
00374                 float dist2 =
00375                         (x * x) + 
00376                         (y * y) + 
00377                         (z * z) + 
00378                         (w * w);
00379 
00380                 float dist =
00381                         (float)sqrt(dist2);
00382                 float scale =
00383                         (float)1.0 / dist;
00384 
00385                 quat[0] = x * scale;
00386                 quat[1] = y * scale;
00387                 quat[2] = z * scale;
00388                 quat[3] = w * scale;
00389         }
00390 };
